message.content:
```json
{
    "ocr_text": "X.                                           March 20, 1899.

Mr. Thos. J. Curtis,

Emmett Association of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners, Union #1806,

150 E. 125th Street, New York City.

Dear Sir and Brother:

I have your favor of the 15th instant in which you refer
to the several local unions of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners
who are considering the subject of affiliating with the American
Federation of Labor. You then inquire in the event of these several
local unions of Peekskill, Storm King, Cornwall, High Falls, Yonkers,
Rossendale, and the Emmett Association becoming affiliated with the
A. F. of L., they could thereafter be organized into a national union
of the craft.

I beg to say in reply that it is always the policy and
practice of the American Federation of Labor to form national unions
of the local unions of any trade or calling whenever there is a
sufficient number of local unions, with a sufficiently large mem-
bership, to warrant the formation of a national organization. You
will therefore understand that the organization of a national union
of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners would depend upon the number
of local unions and the membership represented.

The American Federation of Labor recognizes
the responsibility which devolves upon a national organization,",
    "summary": "The letter, dated March 20, 1899, from the American Federation of Labor addresses Mr. Thos. J. Curtis of the Emmett Association of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners. It discusses the possibility of several local unions affiliating with the Federation and the conditions required to form a national union of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners.",
    "date": "1899-03-20",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```
